item.title: About MetaHikari
item.description:
Static, but Changing

Welcome to MetaHikari, an experiment in static site blog design!

MetaHikari is generated using Pelican, a Python-based, static site generator. I utilize GitHub for free hosting. Since my site is unchanging until I update it, there is no need to worry about maintaining a database for dynamic content.

More importantly, MetaHikari is where I write about my struggles and (minor) triumphs in the worlds of programming and Brazilian jiu jitsu (BJJ).

Please forgive the various design/content changes that will take place as I get things up and running!

Learning to Code the Hard Way

Programming is an activity that can be learned pretty much anywhere these days. There is a long list of options for online learning, such as coursera and opencourseware. I am perhaps a bit old-fashioned and am learning largely through textbooks and friends. I write about my experiences learning code in Tokyo, Japan. Hopefully, I will also attend and write about various programming related meetups in Tokyo.

This blog will document my studies, so it may be of interest to other wannabe hackers and beginners. Learning to code has so far been extremely intellectually rewarding, so I would like to share my enthusiasm about code and (eventually) make some cool stuff.

The Gentle Art

A submission-based, grappling martial art, BJJ places an emphasis on ground fighting and full-speed sparring. Something I love about BJJ is that it challenges both my body and mind. Indeed, the mental aspect is equally as satisfying as the physical training. I train at an awesome gym with a great group of dedicated guys.

As a citizen of Japan, home to numerous traditional martial arts, it is perhaps a bit ironic that I am blogging about a Brazilian system (although even BJJ has its roots in classical Japanese juu-jutsu). Regardless, I thought that other BJJ students around the world would enjoy reading about what training is like in central Tokyo. I will try to keep things interesting!
